conclusion: Object starts from rest and moves under force F; acceleration vs. displacement graph has three regions.
From x = 0 to x = x1, acceleration is constant at a0.
From x = x1 to x = x2, acceleration decreases linearly from a0.
From x = x2 to x = x3, acceleration decreases linearly to zero.
Need to find velocity at displacement x1.
Relationship between acceleration, velocity, and displacement.
For constant acceleration, v^2 = v0^2 + 2 a (x - x0).
Plugging values: v^2 = 0 + 2 a0 (x - 0), so v = sqrt(2 a0 x).
At x = x1, velocity v1 = sqrt(2 a0 x1).
Formula valid for constant acceleration up to x1.
Work-energy principle: Work done W = F * x = m * a0 * x1.
Change in kinetic energy Î”KE = W = (1/2) m v1^2 - 0.
Solving for v1: v1^2 = 2 a0 x1, so v1 = sqrt(2 a0 x1).
Work-energy approach assumes constant force, valid in first segment.
Using definition of acceleration: a = dv/dt, dv/dt = a0.
For t from 0 to t1, x1 = (1/2) a0 t1^2, v = a0 t1.
Solving for t1: t1 = sqrt(2 x1 / a0), then v1 = sqrt(2 a0 x1).
Consistency across methods gives confidence in answer.
Units check: v1 = sqrt(2 a0 x1) has units of m/s.
Physical meaning: object accelerates to x1, then acceleration decreases.
No other forces affect velocity at x1; problem assumes only force F.
Magnitude of velocity at x1 is sqrt(2 a0 x1).
